body: @tauruszhao please use gitter for troubleshooting (PS your version is very old recent is 2.17.0) https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

I have same issue..  when there are 400 errors they are all getting added to ONE trace and eventually it overflows and the client just is blank page.   why does this happen?  What happens is I get this zipkin.flush span when a call gets a 400.   Why do we not just post the span and close the trace?  seems the very first trace just keeps getting these zipkin.flush.js spans the just all collect into one trace and goes on forever until we get this error he is describing...

It's entirely possible something else is going on but i'm pretty sure zipkin-core tests were being run in Travis at some point, and most likely an upgrade of either maven or a plugin made it crash. zipkin-core is really trivial in terms of tests, yet surefire is unable to run them. I'll raise an issue to track, you can either downgrade and let this work out itself - or get out the flashlight and enter the rabbit hole ;-)
let me take this on on. thanks @jorgheymans!

The issue template that was deleted to fill out this issue said we don't use github for questions. Please use gitter https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

There seem to be two questions here.. one is a question about cleanups for MySQL. Another is a question about the zipkin-js project. In both cases, you should talk on gitter. I'll give breadcrumbs but please follow-up on Gitter, not here, as it spams watchers.

on mysql: it is mentioned in our README that mysql is not for production usage. Its schema can result in indexing issues as you just described actually.  The overall storage is mentioned [here](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-storage/mysql-v1), but I'm not going to feed a cleanup job as again, this is not a supported production environment.

on undesirable data: In general, it is best to drop undesirable data before it gets to Zipkin. For example, Brave has "finishedspanhandler". zipkin-js does not have this, but also no one has requested it. Please ask for features on a relevant repo as this repo is for the server.

The closest feature to what's being asked is CollectedSpanHandler. This can drop data for any reason. However, no one has even upvoted the issue. Please express your interest here if you want zipkin to drop data for you https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2807

Regardless, please use gitter first next time.

outside the server, the only thing we use databind for is elasticsearch read requests which is not performance bound (as ES results are way slower than making requests). I only now noticed this from a @bsideup tweet. Seems an easier way to kill a meg https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-jr
Those bars of new design are bars for showing span timestamp and duration, not for showing trace hierarchy... But I can widen the width of the Hierarchy line tree like: **before** **after** WDYT?

what I mean is only ES allows an early write to catastrophically affect query.

in both mysql and cassandra we have offline instructions to add the schema. only cassandra also can self-install it. However, there's no situation like this in cassandra either about a sneaky write killing things.

This is a bug in so far as the health check doesn't ensure schema. However, the way ES behaves adds to the concern. I talked with @basvanbeek about making a commandline option to display what the index template should be. Right now, only ES doesn't have a way to create the schema at setup time (without starting and stopping a zipkin server). This is due to the amount of compatability issues in ES and also that certain parameters are site specific. OTOH, we could probably make a static one that people can hand tune. As far as I know this problem would never occur if there was no possibility of a race in data entering vs index template creation.

wdyt @anuraaga

probably MEM is most intuitive as it matches the default storage type name.
only ES is exceptional in this naming convention iirc

Thanks - left the name and updated the docs

I'll update and rename to MEM_MAX_SPANS

STORAGE_ is used for generic parameters at the moment.

Just to confirm, by health check we're referring to `ElasticsearchStorage.check`? It indeed only checks whether the index is available. Other endpoints like `spanStore` all ensure index templates. But I'm not sure if adding that to health check would change anything - right now, parallel calls to `spanStore` have a race between ensuring indexes, but otherwise parallel calls to `check` would have a similar race IIUC.

This documentation implies that index creation does take some time to propagate to shards

https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-create-index.html#create-index-wait-for-active-shards

My relatively wild guess is that nodes that have had the template propagated to them will respond to the `get-template` request successfully even when other nodes have not created it yet. And now that we're actually round-robining, this means `get-template` can succeed on a node but the span is sent to a following node where it hasn't succeeded yet. One shard will index spans with the template, the other will not (until the next day though when a new index is created, heh). This behavior seems quite dangerous, but I guess to solve it, it would be nice to have an option when indexing to wait for any pending template operations in the cluster which I don't see at https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/docs-index_.html 

Looked through elastic docs to see if they provide a simple way to know status of index templates better (a scatter-gather as we've been implementing recently? ;) ), but can't find any. Simplest way to solve might be to just make sure our `get-template` call succeeds on all endpoints in an `EndpointGroup`.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-storage/elasticsearch/src/main/java/zipkin2/elasticsearch/EnsureIndexTemplate.java#L37

Hopefully someone else can also check that this understanding makes sense.

I think you are right that moving this up wont solve all possible problems
but it would reduce them.

for example if there is no chance a node goes in service without the index
template at least attempted, we are better off.

agree the main issue is there isnt a way to block on completion and also it
is a coordination issue. for example some sites manually control the
template. this means we can't do a content check.

the idea of a fan out on nodes is possible but also not sure the
implications of that and also the overhead..

simultaneously I am working on a cheap cli to make a version specific
template for manual installation based on same env variables

one last thing.. it would be great for ES to create a consistent barrier
for templates. however we still need something now as new features aren't
always back ported.
A CLI for uploading the template for users of multiple nodes is probably the best way anyways :)
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2827 does the scary work. I think it could be an easy change to make a CLI for someone familiar with java
ps I didn't get to this. if someone wants to yank please do
thanks. will visually verify on green!

after:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/66051104-a9b55380-e52e-11e9-98ad-af9557d86ae2.png)

Compared to 2.17 the server jar is about 2MB smaller  (1988790 bytes)

For the record, I think I was the one that pushed for log4j2 in the first
place. no one asked for it. It was slf4j before as default in spring boot.

We don't formally support custom servers anyway, so I wouldn't wander down
that path of plugins etc. OTOH, it is fair to ask what we ourselves want to
use or support.

bear in mind all someone has to do in normal slf4j is to make a layer that
deletes the simple jar and put what they want in. of course switching
completely off slf4j would be more work.

That's a good point - migrating to slf4j-api seems like it has no drawbacks since it's more extensible. Actually it made me realize that by doing that, we'd also have the option of log4j2 backend in the normal image and simple backend in the proposed `slim` distribution - some food for thought :)

yeah provided our deps haven't moved to log4j2, which I don't think
any have.. we can keep watch of that.

@jorgheymans considering what Rag suggested.. I agree. I think also to respect your time most, we should focus this change on moving to slf4j api (including spring boot integration of it), and keeping the old logging backend if possible. We can do a separate pull request to then swap log4j2 the backend out.. taking time with that but without holding the slf4j-api stuff hostage. Make sense?

of course the tests can still use simple etc
google's mirror doesn't seem to be up to date https://maven-central.storage-download.googleapis.com/repos/central/data/

> * performance (? not sure of the real-world impact). By default there aren't many logs, but enabling access logs of server and/or client could have lots and are possibly useful for certain sites.

Honestly i can't tell. Gut feeling says 'simple' should be 'faster' but yeah not always true. It's literally just 5 classes of which 4 dealing with config. https://github.com/qos-ch/slf4j/tree/master/slf4j-simple/src/main/java/org/slf4j/simple . The logging method itself is nothing exotic https://github.com/qos-ch/slf4j/blob/233803688a809fa8ea599306a058351d4c4246a4/slf4j-simple/src/main/java/org/slf4j/simple/SimpleLogger.java#L362 . I'll ask on their user list for perf numbers.

> * Site overrides of log4j.properties. I guess it's fairly simple to override the logging settings at a site, one useful override I can imagine is switching to JSON layout to integrate with JSON-based logging collectors. Is this something we don't support? (just confirming, want to avoid accidentally losing something we do support)

slf4j-simple would not support this indeed.

> * log4j plugins. Similar to above - like how we encourage users to plugin for something like secondary sampling, log4j is nice and pluggable too. Is this something we don't support?

no plugins in slf4j-simple.

> * stability? No clue on this, but I imagine the number of servers that use slf4j-simple in the wild in production is close to zero, wonder if we'll run into something unexpected

that might be a bit speculative, simple logging needs in a more constrained environment (rasp-pi etc) would be a good usecase for this.

> 
> Just want to vet the impact of the change

and thanks for that !

somethings noticed:
TraceId: part is not completely precise when re-rooting. I think we should display the span ID when navigated here.. even better if the url could.

ex show "80f198ee56343ba864fe8b2a57d3eff7-e457b5a2e4d86bd1" if rooted to the ID e457b5a2e4d86bd1 in the trace 80f198ee56343ba864fe8b2a57d3eff7

nice plus would be to instead of showing

http://localhost:9411/zipkin/traces/80f198ee56343ba864fe8b2a57d3eff7
to show

http://localhost:9411/zipkin/traces/80f198ee56343ba864fe8b2a57d3eff7-e457b5a2e4d86bd1

I'm using hyphen format as that is the same as b3 single format https://github.com/openzipkin/b3-propagation#single-header

on duration being only valid starting at 1:
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-api/blob/master/zipkin2-api.yaml#L464

you can make a comment like this

If the API leaves out duration in some cases, it would be nice to set a duration of `1` when fetching and duration is missing since that is the restraint set by the model, and then we don't need to have as many checks at business logic call sites.

I dont quite understand what problem we are solving here. duration query is
expensive so we certainly should not add a constraint like that by default
especially since the query is trace scoped not span scoped. a 1us query
will match even a trace that has spans minus a duration.


also note that Netflix span here was a converted one from a different
system. it is not representative of a proper span, but a flushed span can
also be missing a duration.

with no duration it can fill in 1. The problem that is solved is that
instead of every call site having to check for empty duration, only one
does. It's not expensive.

Since the yaml you linked indicated minimum duration is 1, I figured you were trying to say no duration is the same as 1 but apparently not.

Anyways going to go ahead and pull out of this PR since this isn't helping.

@anuraaga About the duration 1 issue. trying to solve the programming cleanliness indeed does help. Duration 1 as a solution raised strong antibodies, but I don't think that was your original intent. I wanted to make sure that didn't happen as then we would have to immediately undo it. I'm sorry as I was literally presenting at the time, it was hard for me to give complete context.

I'm most concerned about adding a 1 duration as that will make it hard to see errors or incomplete spans. Also, I'm worried about alignments and things, or people wondering why it took 1us. We have an existing issue somewhere to alert people about broken or incomplete traces, and don't want to make that harder to do. That's why I had strong pushback about coercing absent duration to 1.

* When I mentioned that duration 1 is the only valid one I meant to emphasize we can use this to our advantage. That knowing this zero is the same as absent. If we have numerical calculations, we can use zero, in other words.
* when I said "span cleaner" I literally meant src/zipkin/span-cleaner.js. For example, here we add an empty list for annotations for reasons such as this.

So, to put it all together :) I didn't say explicitly, wasn't online really or anything and it was hard for me to see the contexts of the different angles.. but here's the advice.

It is normal to have span cleaning, knowing duration is 0 is same as absent, then change span-cleaner to backfill zero duration. I think this will solve the programming problem. Adding (getting total duration of a row, which I think this comment was about) is ok.

Main thing if we do this is make sure code that does percentage skips span with zero duration: we don't yet know their duration. Be careful to check, that's all. I don't even remember if we do *any* percentage anymore in the UI, so this point might be a relic of the old one.
nit: `REROOT` or `RESET ROOT` instead `RESET REROOT`
+1 to `RESET ROOT` since double-clicking ideally just moves back one root.. the `RESET ROOT` would only be there to go all the way back to root.
for example it is using spans instead of annotations for things like "kong.body_filter"

Notably, there are also spans missing `localEndpoint.serviceName`

Maybe this is something recently fixed in v0.1.3 cc @bungle @jeremyjpj0916
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2834 to try to work around the bad data cc @basvanbeek
Should we add the offending trace to the folder of sample data?
horrible-trace.json? :D
Now unknown instead of undefined in trace list Now, no more white screen rendering this really bad trace:

PS it is tempting to make the span-cleaner fill empty names and such, but it actually would spread debt into other things like clock skew and dependency linker which looks for presence of service names. Instead, I made it a goal to make the white screen go away.

PPS here, Kong should have used an annotation, not an empty span except for timestamp and name. While definitely bad data, I wasn't able to figure out how to get the warning about "no rows found" to go away.
Changes look really nice!  All of the images showing the progression and feedback in the PR is really helpful so thanks to everyone for taking time on those!

This is one that could originate from Envoy and kill Lens.
```
[
  [
```

@jeqo yeah it would be via adding to the classpath using "normal spring" but it is true most probably don't know how to do that. I have a local project I'll resume tonight or tomorrow.

PS occurred to me that we could use a collected span handler to clean up data which results in needless index load, such as the '0' and '-' tags envoy adds. At some point these could be clean from the source, but it is a common problem, and in fact the first streaming project's goal was to clean up bad finagle data!

Ex here there are dubious tags from envoy and probably the shared flag is wrong also. cc @basvanbeek @dio

wait.. maybe I can get around it :P

rewrote the approach cc @anuraaga

TODO: unit tests including that the normal spring conditions still hold (ex disabling an endpoint by config eventhough we enabled it)

> Not using Consumer seems fine but for enlightenment what's the cycle? All it does is call deny which is a static method and seems non-cyclical.

The cycle was in where we provided PrometheusMeterRegistry. The registry type was needed in call sites that themselves defined consumers. Consumers being required to configure the `PrometheusMeterRegistry` was the cycle.
yay it is green, which means our invoker tests work. This proves that actuator is not compile required anymore. I still have some tests to write and also need to double-check performance.
@dsyer I rewrote the rationale in the types to try and avoid saying that things are slow etc.

ps I would like to be honest while avoiding loaded terms. otherwise someone could blindly undo work as they dont understand the underlying problem. in hindsight, "classpath scanning" seems to be emotive. The main thing happening here is disabling autoconfiguration, but that is a what not a why. I suspect there is a way to phrase the why.. for example this stops having to weed through things discovered implicitly via the classpath. for example the factories are primarily discovered via the classpath which is why I used the term scanning though I admit I forgot that was a historical term for something more deep. at any rate some suggestion of a non scary way and also honest would be appreciated.

added tests to 100% coverage and moved rationale around with a note that someone can refactor later as they wish. Since tests are there, it should be possible to do the refactoring safely should one desire. As for me, I'm over budget on this so calling it a day.

> some suggestion of a non scary way and also honest would be appreciated

I think the current wording ("disabling auto-configuration") works.

It might be a good idea to quantify the "significant improvements" though. The Github issue has the figure 10% in the title, and I think that's reasonable. Why not put it in the readme/rationale as well?

loaded a complex setup from zipkin-aws (which is customized to use this) and checked the logs and also the health endpoint.

complex config as it loads both a storage and a collector, using modules and properties loader.
```bash
SQS_QUEUE_URL=https://ap-southeast-1.queue.amazonaws.com/012345678901/zipkin SELF_TRACING_ENABLED=true ES_AWS_DOMAIN=zipkin-ha STORAGE_TYPE=elasticsearch    java  -Dloader.path='elasticsearch-aws.jar,elasticsearch-aws.jar!/lib,sqs.jar,sqs.jar!/lib'  -Dspring.profiles.active=sqs,elasticsearch-aws     -cp zipkin.jar     org.springframework.boot.loader.PropertiesLauncher  --logging.level.zipkin2=DEBUG
```

log shows the modules and also autoconfigure loaded, and show no errors trying to. I also verified this in the health endpoint.
```
2019-10-14 22:06:28.512 DEBUG 99268 --- [           main] z.s.i.ZipkinModuleImporter               : attempting to load modules: [elasticsearch-aws, sqs]
2019-10-14 22:06:28.652 DEBUG 99268 --- [           main] z.s.i.ZipkinActuatorImporter             : attempting to load actuator configuration: [org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.beans.BeansEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.condition.ConditionsReportEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.context.properties.ConfigurationPropertiesReportEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.endpoint.EndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.env.EnvironmentEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.management.HeapDumpWebEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.logging.LoggersEndpointAutoConfiguration, org.springframework.boot.actuate.autoconfigure.management.ThreadDumpEndpointAutoConfiguration]
```
